definition: to take over by force/to rob/to plunder/to brush over/to skim/to sweep

sentences.english: He made them also to be pitied of all those that carried them captives.
sentences.chinese: 他也使他们在凡掳掠他们的人面前蒙怜恤。

sentences.english: And the people went out， and spoiled the tents of the Syrians.
sentences.chinese: 众人就出去，掳掠亚兰人的营盘。

sentences.english: Then the people went out and plundered the camp of the Arameans.
sentences.chinese: 众人就出去，掳掠亚兰人的营盘。

sentences.english: The enemy soldiers liberated chickens and sheep.
sentences.chinese: 敌兵将鸡和羊掳掠一空。

sentences.english: A dyed embroidery, two embroideries, For the neck of the spoiler.
sentences.chinese: 这一两件绣花的彩衣，乃是披在掳掠者颈项上的。

sentences.english: There is hardly a valley or mountainside where folk cannot tell you of some one pillaged from amongst them.
sentences.chinese: 几乎每个山谷或是山麓都不乏关于掳掠的民间故事。

sentences.english: The Edomites had again come and attacked Judah and carried away prisoners
sentences.chinese: 因为以东人又来攻击犹大，掳掠子民。

sentences.english: Horizontal inclined piccolo heartily Be taking captive the pleasant breeze of April.
sentences.chinese: 横斜的短笛尽情在掳掠四月的清风。

sentences.english: Shall the prey be taken from the mighty, or the lawful captive delivered?
sentences.chinese: 勇士抢去的岂能夺回，该掳掠的岂能解救吗。

definition: to massacre everyone in a captured city
to press into service/to impress/to commandeer
not to shrink from any crime (idiom); to commit any imaginable misdeed
ethnic groups in the north and west of China in ancient times/foreigner/barbarian
